name: licensing
title: Licensing
description: How you give people permission to use this data

elements.name: copyrightURL
elements.title: Where have you published the rights statement for this dataset?
elements.description: Give the URL to a page that describes the right to re-use this dataset. This should include a reference to its license, attribution requirements, and a statement about relevant copyright and database rights. A rights statement helps people understand what they can and can't do with the data.

requirement.progressText: Publish a rights statement that details copyright, database rights, licensing and how people should give attribution to the data.

elements.name: dataLicence
elements.title: Under which licence can people reuse this data?

choices.text: Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL)
Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

elements.description: Remember that whoever originally gathers, creates, verifies or presents a database automatically gets rights over it. There may also be copyright in the organisation and selection of data. So people need a waiver or a licence which proves that they can use the data and explains how they can do that legally.

elements.name: dataNotApplicable
elements.title: Why doesn't a licence apply to this data?

choices.text: There are no copyright or database rights in this data
choices.description: Database rights apply if you spent substantial effort gathering, verifying or presenting it. There are no database rights if, for example, the data is created from scratch, presented in an obvious way, and not checked against anything.

choices.text: Copyright and database rights have expired
choices.description: Database rights last ten years. If data was last changed over ten years ago then database rights have expired. Copyright lasts for a fixed amount of time, based on either the number of years after the death of its creator or its publication.

choices.text: Copyright and database rights have been waived
choices.description: This means no one owns the rights and anyone can do whatever they want with this data.

elements.name: dataWaiver
elements.title: Which waiver do you use to waive rights in the data?

choices.text: Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

elements.description: You need a statement to show people the rights have been waived so that they understand they can do whatever they like with this data. Standard waivers already exist like PDDL and CCZero but you can write your own with legal advice.

elements.name: dataOtherWaiver
elements.title: Where is the waiver for the rights in the data?
elements.description: Give a URL to the publicly available waiver so people can check that it does waive the rights in the data.

elements.name: otherDataLicenceName
elements.title: What is the name of the licence?
elements.description: If you use a different licence, we need the name so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate.

elements.name: otherDataLicenceURL
elements.title: Where is the licence?
elements.description: Give a URL to the licence, so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate and check that it's publicly available.

elements.name: otherDataLicenceOpen
elements.title: Is the licence an open licence?
elements.description: If you aren't sure what an open licence is then read the Open Knowledge Definition. Next, choose your licence from the Open Definition Advisory Board open licence list. If a licence isn't in their list, it's either not open or hasn't been assessed yet.

requirement.progressText: You must publish open data under an open licence so that people can use it.

elements.name: contentRights
elements.title: Is there any copyright in the content of this data?

choices.text: No, the data only contains facts and numbers
choices.description: There is no copyright in factual information. If the data does not contain any content that was created through intellectual effort, there are no rights in the content.

choices.text: Yes, and the rights are all held by the same person or organisation
choices.description: Choose this option if the content in the data was all created by or transferred to the same person or organisation.

choices.text: Yes, and the rights are held by different people or organisations
choices.description: In some data, the rights in different records are held by different people or organisations. Information about rights needs to be kept in the data too.

elements.name: explicitWaiver
elements.title: Is the content of the data marked as public domain?
elements.description: Works in the public domain are those whose intellectual property rights have expired, have been forfeited, or are inapplicable. If none of the content of your data have copyright or other rights over it, it is good practice to explicitly state this by labelling it as 'public domain'.

requirement.progressText: You should mark public domain content as public domain so that people know they can reuse it.

elements.name: contentLicence
elements.title: Under which licence can others reuse content?
elements.description: Remember that whoever spends intellectual effort creating content automatically gets rights over it but creative content does not include facts. So people need a waiver or a licence which proves that they can use the content and explains how they can do that legally.

elements.name: contentNotApplicable
elements.title: Why doesn't a licence apply to the content of the data?

choices.text: There is no copyright in the content of this data
choices.description: Copyright only applies to content if you spent intellectual effort creating it, for example, by writing text that's within the data. There's no copyright if the content only contains facts.

Copyright lasts for a fixed amount of time, based on either the number of years after the death of its creator or its publication. You should check when the content was created or published because if that was a long time ago, copyright might have expired.
This means no one owns copyright and anyone can do whatever they want with this data.

elements.name: contentWaiver
elements.title: Which waiver do you use to waive copyright?
elements.description: You need a statement to show people you've done this, so they understand that they can do whatever they like with this data. Standard waivers already exist like CCZero but you can write your own with legal advice.

elements.name: contentOtherWaiver
elements.title: Where is the waiver for the copyright?
elements.description: Give a URL to your own publicly available waiver so people can check that it does waive your copyright.

elements.name: otherContentLicenceName
elements.title: What's the name of the licence?
elements.description: If you use a different licence, we need its name so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate.

elements.name: otherContentLicenceURL
elements.title: Where is the licence?
elements.description: Give a URL to the licence, so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate and check that it's publicly available.

elements.name: otherContentLicenceOpen
elements.title: Is the licence an open licence?
elements.description: If you aren't sure what an open licence is then read the Open Knowledge Definition. Next, choose your licence from the Open Definition Advisory Board open licence list. If a licence isn't in their list, it's either not open or hasn't been assessed yet.

requirement.progressText: You must publish open data under an open licence so that people can use it.

elements.name: contentRightsURL
elements.title: Where are the rights and licensing of the content explained?
elements.description: Give the URL for a page where you describe how someone can find out the rights and licensing of a piece of content from the data.

elements.name: copyrightStatementMetadata
elements.title: Does your rights statement include machine-readable versions of
elements.description: It's good practice to embed information about rights in machine-readable formats so people can automatically attribute this data back to you when they use it.
